I was hired as a lab manager in a lab at the Department of Biomedical Engineering. The professor of associated lab recruited me as a lab manager. As I had postdoc experience, he guaranteed to promote me to research associate within few month. However, he changed his mind because of low source of founds. Furthernore, that professor was always bulling me in front of others. I reported this issue to HR. Unfortunately, they did not have any action because they prefer to save their professor. I was seeking other position at UBC to change my lab. I was a great candidate for many position as I was mostly invited to the interview. However, when professors were realizing that I wanted to change my lab, they were promptly rejected me. Because professors only supports professors for seeking more publication and citations. It is ther buisiness at UBC, Department of Biomedical Engineering. Finally, I decided to leave UBC with many bad experiences. I quiet my job after 4 month and found a great job as a Scientist in a perfect company. I don't recommend this university to whom wants to grow in healthy environment.

review_title: Bad experience overall, I would not recomment UBC for graduate studies.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Vancouver, BC
pros: Relatively high ranking, nice library, beautiful campus.
cons: My PhD was not at all the experience I expected. At least in my department, PhD students work in insalubrious buildings, are barely paid compared to the cost of living in Vancouver, in addition have to pay their own tuition fees, and there is no supervision guidelines: i.e. supervisors are allowed to recruit an infinite amount of students and therefore barely have time to supervise any. With regards to teaching duties, graduate students are usually paid for a number of hours that is grossly underestimated, leaving us with two choices: (i) either we stick with the number of hours we are paid for and we deliver a mediocre experience to undergrads (and are rewarded with bad reviews), or (ii) we spend more time than we are paid for because we feel bad for our students. It really makes us feel like we are just there to publish papers and give grades to undergrads, with no regards to the quality of education or well-being of undergrads and grad students. Moreover, little to nothing is done to help us find career opportunities. Especially for graduate students, no networking event has ever been organized in my 4.5 years at UBC: never have I met anybody from industry at UBC or at an event organized by UBC. Overall I deeply regret coming to UBC for my PhD, and I would advise anybody who is considering it to think twice about the points mentioned above.

cons: Salary is terrible for living in Vancouver unless you have no self-respect and/or decency and are okay with living in a basement (suite, as they call it) even though you are a grown-up with a high level of education (probably more educated than your parents who own property but you don't - what a world!). As a fellow, UBC funds you for 4 years but most programs take longer than that to complete, so good luck if you run out of funding! People are stuck up and think they're better than everyone because they work for UBC (which actually sucks!). Just RUN as far away as you can from UBC.

review_title: Great Benefits, Decent Salary, Poor Communication
job_title: IT Support Analyst in Vancouver, BC
pros:
- The people are amazing. Really diverse backgrounds and experiences. Always make for good conversation.

- Being a public institution, the benefits are fantastic, especially extended health and the pension.

- Decent work life balance, you're not expected to work past 5. Plus you get extra holidays compared to other places (e.g.: Easter Monday, National Day for Truth & Reconciliation, Winter Break).

- Campus is absolutely beautiful.
cons:
- Not a lot of potential for upward growth unless you switch departments/teams. Largely due to people staying around for a long time.

- Salary is decent but definitely subpar. Have still seen lower salaries though for equal positions.

- Communication is horrible (this probably varies from department to department). We often wouldn't be told of expectations by our directors, nor be told of deadlines for items until less than a week before.

- You pretty often have work to do that doesn't relate to your position.

- You have to work overtime pretty often due to not having enough staff members and the overall workload.

job_title: Operations Staff Team Lead in Vancouver, BC
pros:
- Everyone is helpful, willing to teach each other and be there to support you when you are in need. 
- Supervisors were great, they were so down-to-earth and approachable. They were always working on improving and always prioritized our mental and physical wellbeing 
- Working in different environments (at different facilities that we manage) so you don't get bored.
- You are mobile and you get to burn calories! (always moving around, being quick on your feet)
cons:
- As a team lead, the raise isn't much higher than the regular operations staff salary (but you learn a lot being a team lead) 
- If you value consistency in terms of who you work with, you might not get that being an operations staff at the Student Recreation Centre. Due to the fact that there are many staff, you are always working with different people! (may be favorable for you if you like working with a diverse number of people)

job_title: Senior Program Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: Secure, reliable - career development laterally if not promotion wise. Campus is nice. Better the devil you know for me. I wish I did not start working here. It sucks you in - and stunts growth.
cons: HR here protects the university and their team. They are not here for you. The union is if you are in CUPE. Biased management/nepotism ; though work The culture really varies according to department. I've worked 3-4 over several years. Salary is woeful - I have deskilled working here after switching industries but have little stress. It is like any other higher education environment - slow, silos, too much bureaucracy. No flexibility in my dept despite claiming otherwise, do as you are told in CUPE basically, stopping just short of assigned washroom breaks

This isn't necessary a place for growth but more a place for stability.

pros:
- excellent benefits: dental and extended medical are some of the best benefits that myself or medical practitioners usually see
- good job security: unionized so very secure
- excellent vacation and pension plan
cons:
- honestly, experience will vary so widely depending on position and department - I've had both an amazing UBC manager and a horrible one
- unionized structure makes it incredibly difficult to move career forward (in order to apply for a new position you need to go through the complete application process. You receive an elevated application status if you are applying to a job in the same union as you are currently in, but moving to a different union is like starting at square one)
- I currently am at the higher end of my union, so to move up in my career I either need to leave UBC or apply to another union which is an uphill process
- very bureaucratic and lots of red tape
- certain individuals and departments enjoy the hierarchical nature of the university, which can be frustrating as admin support (lots of inflated egos)
- very static environment (due to both the red tape, and due to the nature of working in a school  [very cyclical and focused on the same procedures and events every year])
- lower wage than one would make in similar positions outside UBC (although made up for largely with benefits)

pros: decent wages and interesting work.
